title: Travel briefs
text:
Columbus, Ohio • Sep 20, 2015 • 62° Clear The Columbus Dispatch Need help? Visit our FAQ page or use our Contact Form . Customer Service Need help? Try our live chat or online customer service . For service, call 1-877-734-7728. For other inquiries, use our Contact Form or Staff Directory . Subscriptions Subscribe to The Dispatch online or call 1-877-734-7728. Advertising To place help wanted ads, call 614-888-8888 or visit ColumbusJobs.com For private seller and classified advertising, call 614-888-8888 or visit DispatchClassifieds.com . For retail advertising, call 614-461-5500 or email us . For national advertising, call 614-461-5199. For online advertising, call 614-461-5143 or email us . Newsroom Use our Contact Form , or call 614-461-5200. Dispatch Careers Visit dispatch.com/careers or call 614-461-5033. Fax 614-461-5565. Sunday September 20, 2015 5:00 AM Columbo event set at resort 
Rumpled, bumbling TV detective Columbo will be celebrated by the murder-mystery adventure players Shadow Stalkers when they bring “Columbo’s Last Case” to the Kelleys Island Venture Resort on Oct. 9 and 10. 
Guests will be invited to do their own Columbo impersonation during the event, which runs nonstop at sites around the island from check-in until the mystery is solved and prizes are awarded. (As many as 13 guests have been “murdered” during previous Shadow Stalker events.) Reservations begin at $145 per night. 
For room reservations, call 419-746-2900. For information about Shadow Stalkers, visit www.shadowstalkers.net Apple butter to be made 
The air will fill with the scents of wood fires burning and apples cooking at the Apple Butter Making Festival, Wednesday through Saturday at Sauder Village near Archbold in northwestern Ohio. 
Guests can watch as demonstrators make apple butter, press cider and cook other apple treats. The site’s Founder’s Hall will also host a Fiber Arts Fest on Saturday and next Sunday. 
Call 1-800-590-9755 or visit www.saudervillage.org Disney light show to end 
Walt Disney World has announced that this year will be the last for the Osborne family’s Christmas light spectacle at Disney’s Hollywood Studios because of plans to use the space for new Star Wars - and Toy Story -themed areas. 
The display of dancing lights has been a Christmas tradition at Disney World for 20 years.
